author: elementarysoftware
title: Standard SSI templates library
description: There are no standards for which properties a digital credential must contain. Without standards, verification will be impossible

f6_assessments.q0: Sometimes the simplest things can have the most impact.  Of all the proposals in this challenge setting, this one has perhaps the most universal impact, as it could conceivably be used by half or more of the other projects.  The goal is straightforward:  build out an extensive, expandable, forkable opensource library of standard SSI, VC and DID credential templates.  Beyond just the ability for an event venue to grab a "ticket" template or for a highschool to grab a "diploma" template to use in their own SSI schemes, a homeschool curriculum could fork a "diploma" template and adapt it to its own particular case, and in the process expand the library for everyone else.  And the scalability doesn't end there:  the repository root could be expanded to include templates for SSI concepts like "Claims" (what standard statements can be made about subjects) or "Presentations" (what standard selective views might be selected by holders of data credentials).  Libraries of this nature could experience exponential growth and have their own OSS communities dedicated to maintaining them.  But it has to start somewhere.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer does a good job of delimiting the scope of this library to a readily executable subset of templates, and wisely makes community collaboration an early goal.  The timeline starts with developing protocols for community communication and creation of templates, a "template of templates" approach that should pay dividends down the line.  It quickly moves into execution and development of the library, taking into account the need for dedicated communication protocols to manage contributions in an orderly fashion, and that is where most of the time and budget is spent.  Finally, a solid QA and rollout phase is included where the last budget fumes should be enough to push the project over the finish line.  The budget itself is timed to the these phases, but it would be ideal if we could see a bit more granularity from the development budget (how many hours are we talking here and is $15k enough?).  However the percentage of the budget apportioned to each area (development 71%, documentation 19%, communications/nmanagement 10%) all seem very appropriate.  There is very little risk associated with this project.  Worst case scenario there is not a lot of community involvement, and the Library is built out only enough to suit this proposer's associated DID project, but it would still be opensource and still publicly available to be expanded.
f6_assessments.q2: As an opensource project the proposer intends to make the Library available from first notes to final implemenation.  The proposer's intention to work with the community to expand the templates submitted means they will have open, accessible channels of communication for the project.  They also indicate familiarity with the IOG protocols for monthly progress and KPI reporting.  In this case, the KPIs to be reported (commits, community engagement) should be easy enough to track and include in the audits, and the Library itself will be available at all times to include along with a changelog for simple, easy to understand reports.  There is an elegant simplicity to this project, and it is really driven home in the transparency and ease with which it should be able to be audited.  This is a classic Catalyst proposal in line with the best principles of the community.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer looks to create a set of templates that can be used within the SSI ecosystem. No easy to use and well thought of standards have been created in the identity space and the execution of this proposal could help to provide insight in what some suitable standards could be. As the proposer mentions there are many variations and types of credentials. This task is not an easy one as without the use cases of the credentials being explored it will be hard to say beforehand the exact data that will be required in the credentials. The requirements in many instances could evolve and mutate based on the evolution of the identity market and the types of data that are valuable to be used in certain credential types. There is definitely a need for efforts towards standardisation however due to the inherent risks of a large number of approaches emerging making the interconnectivity between multiple applications more expensive and confusing in terms of a technical implementation. It would have been good for the proposer to suggest some of the risks that if they did make good standards that there is a risk that they could not foresee some evolution of the market and as such that standard actually becomes a burden instead of an effective data model for certain credential types. Overall there is value to exploring this work and seeing what standards come out of it - the proposer would definitely benefit from considering how to be more specific on credential areas that are more predictable where possible!
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer breaks down the roadmap into monthly deliveries each with a set of itemised tasks. A simple budget is broken down based upon the areas of work with a total cost provided. The proposer provides their information regarding themselves and a LinkedIn profile to showcase their background. The timeline is reasonable given the work mentioned as they have provided multiple months to interact with people across the ecosystem as well as their creation of the templates. The proposer has a sufficient technical background and a simple and reasonable plan to execute the proposal that has been presented.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal team provide a set of KPIs that cover tracking the deliverables of the project. As well as the delivery of the templates this is also where being more specific on the credential focus areas would be useful. Metrics based off these focus areas could then be created where the proposer could have looked to onboard a number of projects that require a credential of this type. On it's own the work should still provide inspiration to other creators in the identity space though it would have been useful to be more specific than SSI creators and SSI tools alike.
